Editorial and format changes were made throughout this IRM section. Additional information may be found on the SROC SharePoint.https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/SbseHCOWFPR/LR/SROC/
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.53.1 dated August 1, 2007.
Table of Contents
Organizational Change
) On October
, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) officially as part of the new, modernized IRS. As the second largest Business Division (BOD), SB/SE has approximately
IRS employees engaged the full range of programs associated with tax administration. (
) The SB/SE Request for Organizational Change (SROC) process has been place since February

and is administered by the SB/SE Human Office (SHCO). A review of this IRM was initiated to identify areas for ment and incorporate revisions to the organizational change process. Accordingly, the SB/SE organizational change policy and procedures have been reﬁned to align the current business needs with customer demands. (
) IRM
, Managing Organizational Change, provides an overview and cedures for requesting organizational changes to the SB/SE organizational and structure. (

) Purpose: This IRM Section is to establish standardized policies and proce- dures to govern the review and approval of proposed organizational within the SB/SE Division. The review, concurrence and approval process the request will depend on the scope and magnitude of the requested changes. (

) Audience: Employees and managers in the SB/SE Division preparing for organizational changes: • Collection • Examination • Operations Support • Office of Fraud Enforcement (OFE) • Office of Promoter Investigations (OPI) (
) Policy Owner: Director, SB/SE Human Capital Office (SHCO). (
) Program Owner: Leadership Development and Support Office (LDSO) within SHCO. (

) The purpose of the SROC program is to serve as the means for approval of SB/SE organizational design changes. The SROC process is ﬁrst step that should be taken to obtain ﬁnal approval of the request for zational change. The SROC process is not intended as a replacement for routine processes which are already in place to secure funding of additional positions, upgrades, etc. (
) The objective of this process is to provide consistency and ensure that proposal to reorganize the current structure of SB/SE is properly evaluated, approved and implemented. (
) The SROC program ensures all proposed changes adhere to current management and classiﬁcation guidelines and proper notiﬁcation has been provided to National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU). (
) The SROC program is required to request new organizational codes, or deactivate organizational codes. (
) The guidance is intended to serve as a framework for managing the tional change process. It outlines the responsibilities of key officials and (

The purpose of the SROC program is to serve as the means for documenting approval of SB/SE organizational design changes. The SROC process is the ﬁrst step that should be taken to obtain ﬁnal approval of the request for zational change. The SROC process is not intended as a replacement for the routine processes which are already in place to secure funding of additional
The guidance is intended to serve as a framework for managing the organiza- tional change process. It outlines the responsibilities of key officials and
1.53 Small Business/Self-Employed
Small provides procedures for processing and evaluating proposals. The will differ depending upon the type of organizational change request. (
) Organizational changes should improve the effectiveness and/or efficiency an organization through the optimum use of staff and resources, while plishing organizational goals and objectives. (

) The following principles govern organizational design within the SB/SE Division. Organizational structures should be designed to: • Establish business practices which provide the highest level of service at the lowest possible cost • Eliminate unnecessary supervisory positions and organizational • Utilize the talents and capabilities of all employees (

) Once a decision is made to modify any current structure, it should be nicated and implemented in a manner that: • Supports the Strategic Plan • Minimizes disruption to business operations • Ensures the continuity of essential employee services • Promotes efficiency within SB/SE (

) The Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support (DCOS) instituted a six- month rule that freezes subsequent transitions affecting the same Business units are not permitted to submit an SROC when there are in the employees’ work, organizational structure, or transition efforts for six months from approval of the prior SROC. Exceptions to the Six-Month Rule: When there is no change in organizational codes When there is only a change in the organizational name Movement of an employee or group of employees corrects a staffing imbalance or Span of Control (SOC) issue, where the resources did not materialize as originally planned by the SROC and there is no change in working conditions to the employees being realigned/ reassigned (e.g., series, grade or work) (

) The SB/SE Commissioner has designated the Director, SHCO, as the sible Executive for overseeing the governing policy for SB/SE change proposals to meet these objectives and ensure full and open cation at all levels. Within SHCO, the Chief, LDSO will serve as the focal for controlling and coordinating organizational change proposals. In LDSO will serve as the official repository of all documentation associated organizational change proposals and decisions. (
) SB/SE Executives are responsible for ensuring sound organizational by continually evaluating the effectiveness and efficiency of their business units.

Establish business practices which provide the highest level of service at the lowest possible cost
Eliminate unnecessary supervisory positions and organizational

Supports the Strategic Plan
Minimizes disruption to business operations
Ensures the continuity of essential employee services

The SB/SE Commissioner has designated the Director, SHCO, as the respon
sible Executive for overseeing the governing policy for SB/SE organizational change proposals to meet these objectives and ensure full and open communi

cation at all levels. Within SHCO, the Chief, LDSO will serve as the focal point for controlling and coordinating organizational change proposals. In addition, LDSO will serve as the official repository of all documentation associated with organizational change proposals and decisions. SB/SE Executives are responsible for ensuring sound organizational structures by continually evaluating the effectiveness and efficiency of their business
Change
page (

) The SROC process only approves the organizational design change. Once SROC has been approved, the implementation of the new design (e.g., positions) must be done in accordance with current Finance and Position agement Guidelines. Furthermore, after a change has been approved, it is responsibility of the initiating SB/SE Executive to ensure that the change is properly implemented, all applicable systems have been updated and any Labor Relations issues have been resolved prior to implementation. (

) Approval Authority & Limitations: The levels of review and approval for SROCs will vary due to the nature of the request. Once the SROC has been approved, the implementation of the new design (e.g., ﬁlling positions) must done in accordance with current Finance and Human Capital guidelines. (
) Approving Originating SB/SE Executive: The SB/SE Executive who promotes the organizational change and ensures that it is properly imple- mented subsequent to approval. (
) Approving SB/SE Executive: The next level SB/SE Executive above the Approving Originating SB/SE Executive. (

) Business Case Memo: Memorandum prepared by the originating office and included in the SROC package outlining the justiﬁcation for the change as required by Corporate Human Capital Office (CHCO). The case includes the desired outcome, and other facts (e.g., workforce plan) essential for the approving official to make a well-informed decision. (
) Classiﬁcation: The analysis and evaluation of a position to include pay category, title, series and grade level. (

) Directed Reassignment: An involuntary action initiated by the agency to the movement of an employee from one position to another without or change to lower grade (CLG) (e.g., movement to a new occupational or to another position in the same series and grade level), where an and their position is realigned to a location outside of the commuting area. (
) Functional Statements: Statements that clearly deﬁne the purpose and re- sponsibilities of each segment of the organization. Current SB/SE Functional Statements are located in IRM
Small Business/Self-Employed (

) Job Abolishment: The termination of a position where the duties are elimi- nated entirely or combined with duties of another position(s). Job does not involve situations where: • There is no material change in official job duties and responsibilities • The position is re-described • A paperwork transaction eliminates one position and creates another • There is a change in title and/or series only (
) Mass Update Module (MUM): An application in HR Connect that HR ists use to process a large volume of the same type of personnel actions. (
) Operating Units: The internal business units that comprise SB/SE (Exam, lection, Operations Support, OFE and OPI). (

) Organizational Change: Any change to an organization’s structure, geo- graphic boundaries, management structure, organizational mission or or business processes that may or may not result in a change in the Internal Revenue Manual
Organizational Change 1.53.1

Organizational Change: Any change to an organization’s structure, geo- graphic boundaries, management structure, organizational mission or function, or business processes that may or may not result in a change in the
1.53 Small Business/Self-Employed

The change may involve realignment, reorganization, or restructuring. Changes may result in abolishment of current positions, creation of new positions that did not previously exist in SB/SE, changes to position titles, series and grades, and/or excess employees. (

) Organizational Charts: A diagram of boxes that shows the structure of an or- ganization and the reporting hierarchy. Each box should contain: • Name of group, team, department, etc, and number of positions • Position title/pay plan/series/grade/PD #, BU Status (e.g., Internal Revenue Agent, GS-
, BU) • Employee name, POD and building code • Vacant positions (

) Organizational Codes: Any location within SB/SE that has a manager position is assigned its own unique set of organizational codes (e.g., groups, territories, teams or departments, etc.). The set of codes consists of Treasury Integrated Management Information System (TIMIS) codes, title, SETR and Department ID organizational codes. Note: The current list of SB/SE organizational codes are located at the following

The change may involve realignment, reorganization, or restructuring. Changes may result in abolishment of current positions, creation of new positions that did not previously exist in SB/SE, changes to position titles, series and grades, and/or excess employees.

http://hco.web.irs.gov/PPS/orgcode/OrgCodeSpreadsheets.html

Point of Contact (POC): The individual employee who is assigned primary responsibility for development and coordination of the SROC. The individual should have complete knowledge and understanding of the proposal and access to the Approving Originating Executive. Positional Description (PD): An official written statement of the major duties, responsibilities and supervisory relationships of a position.
Positional Description (PD): An official written statement of the major responsibilities and supervisory relationships of a position.
Note: The IRS PD library is located at the following link:
https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/HCOETS/PMC/SPDLibrary/Sit
ages/Home.aspx (

) Position Management: The structuring of positions into the most efficient effective organization to accomplish the mission. Position Management is concerned with such issues as job design, career ladder development, ratio supervisors to subordinates (span of control), appropriate use of assistants, types of positions, and cost/beneﬁt analysis. (

) Realignment: The movement of an employee from one organization to another. A realignment does not result in any impact to an employee’s position or status (e.g., series or grade, work schedule, and/or pay (including locality pay)). (
) Reassignment: The movement of an employee from their current position to another vacant approved position, without promotion or change to lower level or pay band. (
) Span of Control (SOC): Ratio of supervisor to direct reports.
Organizational Change 1.53.1

Depending on the nature, scope, cost, and expected impact of recommended organizational changes, all proposed changes will be assigned to one of three categories (A, B or C) . Most requests fall under either Category A or B.

Create new groups or teams Create new territories or departments Realign employees Collapse existing organizational structures (groups, territories, teams, departments, etc.) Eliminate vacant positions that are no longer needed Rename group, team, etc.

positions • Change the title, series, or grade of a position • Increase/Decrease span of control for an occupational series • Transfer management and program responsibility from one SB/SE Operating Unit (OU) to another • Create new positions that did not previously exist in the OU Category C involves major organizational changes within whose scope and impact directly affect other Business Operating W&I, LB&I, TEGE). Examples are listed below. • Create/abolish/merge Areas and Divisions • Substantially modify employment base in any state • Close/move Posts of Duty and Customer Service Assistance • Close/build/move an IRS facility • Create occupation upgrades • Changes that impact National Labor Agreements • Transfer management and program responsibility from one division to another • Create new positions that did not previously exist in the IRS • IRS Servicewide changes in authority, function, or scope of activities • Directed Reassignment • Create/abolish/promote Executive level positions All new Executive positions require approval from the Corporate Human

1.53 Small Business/Self-Employed
Note: Contact the SROC POC to obtain the most recent organizational chart
• Structure of organization which includes proposed changes Combined EDI and Impacted Employee Listing • Listing contains all impacted employees (BU and NBU) Form
, Notice to National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) • Used to notify NTEU when BU employees are impacted For additional information, refer to the SROC Desk Guide on the
The SROC package will be reviewed for completeness and to ensure:

a. SROC Template and Business Case Memo clearly deﬁne the purpose and justiﬁcation of the proposed changes b. Span of Control (SOC) guidelines are met c. Positions Descriptions (PDs) are valid and current d. Organizational Charts accurately reﬂect proposed changes e. All impacted employees are shown on the Combined EDI and Employee Listing f. Form

is included when BU employees are impacted g. Employees are not adversely affected h. Current vacant positions are identiﬁed on both the current and organizational charts i. New vacant positions are identiﬁed on the proposed organizational j. All name changes are labeled on the proposed organizational charts After the review process has been completed, the SROC package is to internal and external stakeholders for approval, based upon the type of request. Approvals may include: a. SB/SE Leadership b. Equity, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI) c. Chief Financial Officer (CFO) d. Corporate Human Capital Office (CHCO) e. Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support (DCOS)
Organizational Change 1.53.1

ensuring: a. Personnel Action Requests (PARs) and system changes (e.g., ICS, Concur, RGS, etc.) are initiated and completed timely b. NTEU notiﬁcation process has been completed c. Labor Relations issues are resolved prior to implementation d. Implementation of the new design (e.g., ﬁlling positions) is completed in accordance with current Finance and Human Capital guidelines
New organizational codes will be provided with the approved SROC package.
Note: Realignments of 75 or more employees require a MUM.
